comments: Bifidobacterium longum subsp. longum ATCC 55813.A reference genome for the Human Microbiome Project.

isolation_comments: isolated from cream cheese
comments: Bacillus cereus m1293. This strain, also known as BPS-2, was isolated from cream cheese and will be used for comparative analysis with other Bacillus cereus strains.

isolation_comments: isolated from soil
comments: Bacillus mycoides DSM 2048. Bacillus mycoides DSM 2048, also known as ATCC 6462, was isolated from soil.  This is the type strain and will be used for comparative analysis with other Bacillus mycoides strains.

isolation_comments: isolated from human blood in Iceland
comments: Bacillus cereus AH1273. This strain was isolated from human blood in Iceland and will be used for comparative analysis with other Bacillus cereus strains.

sequencing_centers: Center for Genomic Sciences, Allegheny-Singer Research Institute
isolation_comments: isolated from soil in New York State by alkaline enrichment cultures
comments: Bacillus pseudofirmus OF4. This strain was isolated from soil in New York State by alkaline enrichment cultures. Because of its pH range and genetic accessibility, this alkaliphile has been extensively used as the model organism for studies of the bioenergetics of life at extremely high pH.

isolation_source: patient who suffered severe inhalational anthrax
isolation_comments: isolated from a patient who suffered severe inhalational anthrax in 2001 from West Palm Beach, Florida
comments: Bacillus anthracis str. A2012. This strain (Florida isolate, cat. A2012, Ames genotype) was isolated from a patient who suffered severe inhalational anthrax in 2001 from West Palm Beach, Florida. It was sequenced in conjunction with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's analysis of the letter attacks that occurred in 2001.

isolation_source: the axilla of a bone marrow transplant patient
isolation_comments: isolated from the axilla of a bone marrow transplant patient
comments: Corynebacterium jeikeium K411.This strain was isolated from the axilla of a bone marrow transplant patient.

isolation_comments: obtained by E. Freundt at the Institue of Medical Microbiology, University of Aarhus, Aarhus, Denmark
comments: Ureaplasma parvum serovar 3 str. ATCC 700970. Ureaplasma parvum serovar 3 is the serovar most commonly isolated from humans and this strain was obtained by E. Freundt at the Institue of Medical Microbiology, University of Aarhus, Aarhus, Denmark.

isolation_comments: isolated during an outbreak in 1982
comments: Escherichia coli O157:H7. This strain is associated with Hamburger disease, which is caused by the contamination of meat products by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). The identifier O157:H7 refers to the serotype of EHEC, and reflects the specific antigenic markers found on the surface of the cell. EHEC attaches and effaces to cells in the large intestine.  There are numerous differences that distinguish O157:H7 from K-12, hundreds of them associated with genomic islands in either strain, including at least 9 large PAIs in O157:H7 that encode virulence factors. A type III secretion system, the locus of enterocyte effacement, numerous toxins and adhesins, as well as fimbrial gene clusters and iron uptake systems are found in these PAIs. Pathogenicity genes are also found on the plasmid pO157.  Escherichia coli O157:H7 strain EDL933. This strain (substrain) is considered a reference strain of O157:H7, which was first isolated during an outbreak in 1982.
Chlamydia muridarum Nigg. This is a wild-type strain that is virulent in mice.

genome_name: Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor str. N16961
organism_name: Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor str. N16961
isolation_source: the classical biotype due to hemolysin production
isolation_comments: isolated in 1971 in Bangladesh and is distinguished from the classical biotype due to hemolysin production
comments: Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar ElTor str. N16961.This is an epidemic serogroup of Vibrio cholerae isolated in 1971 in Bangladesh and is distinguished from the classical biotype due to hemolysin production. It contains 2 chromosomes. The first, and larger chromosome, contains many essential cell functions, as well as virulence genes contained within pathogenicity islands (PAIs). One major pathogenicity determinant is encoded within a PAI that is contained inside an integrated phage (CTXphi) on chromosome 1 that codes for the cholera toxin, an adenylate cyclase. Once the toxin is injected into host cells, it results in secretion of chlorine ions, which leads to increased water secretion, dehydration, and eventually, death. Up to 20 litres of water a day may be lost. The second chromosome also has important cell functions, but has a preponderance of genes associated with energy and transport functions, including signal transduction systems, and in addition, DNA repair enzymes. Chromosome 2 also has the integron island, a large variable region of the chromosome that functions as a gene capture system, some of which are associated with antibiotic resistance. There are 105 genes that have copies on both chromosomes.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa strain PA01. This strain contains one of the largest bacterial genomes ever sequenced which consists of a circular chromosome of 6,264,403 bp. It is the most widely used Pseudomonas aeruginosa laboratory strain.

isolation_comments: isolated from a patient with a wound infection
comments: Streptococcus pyogenes strain M1 GAS. This strain is also known as group A streptococci (GAS). This organism is a strict human pathogen that was isolated from a patient with a wound infection.

genome_name: Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida str. Pm70
organism_name: Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida str. Pm70
isolation_comments: isolated in 1995 from a case of fowl cholera in chickens
comments: Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida str. Pm70. Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida str. Pm70 was isolated in 1995 from a case of fowl cholera in chickens. This strain is a serotype 3 capsular type A strain and will provide information on the production and regulation of proteins involved in virulence and disease.

isolation_comments: isolated from a patient with disseminated gonococcal infections
comments: Neisseria gonorrhoeae strain FA 1090. A serum-resistant streptomycin-resistant proline-requiring strain isolated from a patient with disseminated gonococcal infections.

sequencing_centers: Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique (INRA)
isolation_source: derivative of strain IL594 isolated from a cheese starter culture.
isolation_comments: derivative of strain IL594 isolated from a cheese starter culture.
comments: Lactococcus lactis subsp. lactis. This subspecies is used to make soft cheeses.  Lactococcus lactissubsp. lactis Il1403. This strain is used widely in laboratory research and is a plasmid-free derivative of strain IL594 isolated from a cheese starter culture. The genome shows many insertion sequences and prophages, and surprisingly, a large number of genes involved in respiration, suggesting that this organism may aerobically respire.

isolation_source: the blood of a 30 year old male patient
isolation_comments: isolate from the blood of a 30 year old male patient in Kongsvinger, Norway
comments: Streptococcus pneumoniae strain TIGR4. This strain is a highly virulent capsular serotype 4 clinical isolate from the blood of a 30 year old male patient in Kongsvinger, Norway.
Caulobacter crescentus strain CB15. This is a wild-type strain and will be used for comparative analysis.

isolation_comments: isolated in 1984 from a patient in Beijing, China
comments: Shigella flexneri 2a str. 301. This strain was isolated in 1984 from a patient in Beijing, China. It is similar to pathogenic Escherichia coli except for the more numerous insertion sequences and contains a virulence plasmid (pCP301).

genome_name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2 strain LT2; SGSC 1412; ATCC 700720
isolation_comments: isolated in the 1940s by Lilleengen, and typed based on phage sensitivity
comments: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar typhimurium strain LT2. This strain was first isolated in the 1940s by Lilleengen, and typed based on phage sensitivity. It became the principle laboratory strain and many important biochemical and genetic experiments were performed using this strain, including classical phage transduction studies. LT2 contains a plasmid, pSLT, that encodes additional virulence functions. Numerous prophages, some of which contain virulence genes, are inserted into the chromosome of LT2 as compared to related Salmonella.

Sinorhizobium meliloti strain 1021. Streptomycin resistant derivative of strain 2011. This strain carries 2 megaplasmids, pSymA and pSymB. Nitrogen fixation functions and nodulation genes are found on pSymA. The second plasmid encodes a number of transport systems, including many ABC-type transporters. This organism does not have a type III secretion system like the other Rhizobia but does have a type IV secretion system.

isolation_comments: isolated from a New Zealand high-sulfide hot spring
comments: Chlorobium tepidum strain TLS. This green-sulfur bacterium is a  thermophile and was isolated from a New Zealand high-sulfide hot spring. It is a model organism for studying this group of bacteria due to its ease of cultivation and transformability.

isolation_comments: isolated from a human in South Africa
comments: Rickettsia conorii strain Malish 7. This strain was isolated from a human in South Africa.
Streptococcus pneumoniae strain R6. This strain is an avirulent descendent of a type 2 capsule S clinical isolate used by Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty to demonstrate the genetic function of DNA.

isolation_comments: isolated from a hot spring in Tengcong, China, and is the type strain for the species
comments: Thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis strain MB4. This organism was originally isolated from a hot spring in Tengcong, China, and is the type strain for the species. Genomic analysis indicates it is similar to Bacillus halodurans and that it has one of the most biased leading strand distribution of genes. Although the organism has not been observed to be motile or to sporulate, it does contain genes for both functions. The bacterium produces acetate and ethanol from glucose and cannot degrade xylan and cellulose.

genome_name: Zymomonas mobilis subsp. mobilis ZM4 = ATCC 31821
isolation_comments: isolated from fermenting sugarcane juice and is wild-type and unable to utilize xylose
comments: Zymomonas mobilis subsp. mobilis strain ZM4. This strain was isolated from fermenting sugarcane juice and is wild-type and unable to utilize xylose.

isolation_comments: isolated from an infected goat and is pathogenic in humans
comments: Brucella melitensisstrain 16M. This strain was isolated from an infected goat and is pathogenic in humans.

genome_name: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris str. ATCC 33913
organism_name: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris str. ATCC 33913
isolation_comments: isolated from cabbage
comments: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris str. ATCC 33913. This strain was originally isolated from cabbage. The genome contains 2 different type II secretion systems for the export of extracellular enzymes such as cellulases that degrade the plant cell wall. It contains a single type III secretion system (Hrp) that is important for pathogenicity and has genes that allow colonziation and systemic infection.

Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. citri str. 306. This strain contains genes that are similar to genes from another citrus pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa. It has 2 different type II secretion system for the export of extracellular enzymes that degrade the plant cell wall including cellulases. The genome encodes a single type III secretion system (Hrp) that is important for pathogenicity as well as two type IV secretion system, one on the chromosome and one found on one of the two plasmids this organism contains, pXAC64.

isolation_source: child's conjunctiva (the membranes lining the eyelid) during a trachoma vaccine trial
isolation_comments: isolated in 1965 from a child's conjunctiva (the membranes lining the eyelid) during a trachoma vaccine trial in Taiwan
comments: Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain TW-183. This is the type strain for Chlamydophila pneumoniae. An ocular isolate first isolated in 1965 from a child's conjunctiva (the membranes lining the eyelid) during a trachoma vaccine trial in Taiwan. However, it naturally causes respiratory rather than ocular infections.

isolation_comments: isolated in 1998 from a naturally infected Californian grapevine
comments: Xylella fastidiosa strain Temecula1. This strain was isolated in 1998 from a naturally infected Californian grapevine.
Streptococcus agalactiae strain 2603V/R. This strain is a serotype V clinical isolate and is the most common type amoung GBS-infected (group B streptococcal) non-pregnant adults.
Streptococcus pyogenes strain MGAS8232. This strain is a serotype M18 strain often associated with acute rheumatic fever outbreaks in the USA.

isolation_comments: symbiont of the aphid Schizaphis graminum
comments: Buchnera aphidicola strain Sg (Schizaphis graminum). This strain is the symbiont of the aphid Schizaphis graminum and contains a large circular chromosome.

Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae strain KACC10331. This plant pathogen affects rice plants by causing leaf blight, a major problem in Asian countries where rice production occurs on an industrial scale. Losses of up to 50% of the total crop can occur in extreme cases. This pathogen enters the xylem and spreads throughout the vascular tissue of the plant, which results in wilting of the plant, or to leaf blight if the infection occurs later in development. This organism shares common virulence determinants with Xanthomonas campestris including an hrp (hypersensitive response) system that is a type III secretion system for delivery of effector molecules to the host cell cytoplasm, and avr (avirulence) genes. Other pathogenicity determinants include extracellular polysaccharide, adhesins, a type II secretion system and the extracellular enzymes secreted by it, as well as some toxins. This organism encodes 245 proteins that are not found in other Xanthomonas pathogens.;many frameshifted proteins

Shigella flexneri 2a str. 2457T. This is a highly virulent strain that has been widely used for genetic and clinical research. It is similar to pathogenic Escherichia coli except for the more numerous insertion sequences and contains 4 plasmids pINV-2457T, pSf2, and pSf4, and pSf-R27. Plasmid pINV-2457T is similar to plasmids pWR100, pWR501, and pCP301 whereas plasmid pSf-R27 is similar to R27. Plasmids pSf2 and pSf4 are small ColE1-like plasmids. pSf2 is similar to plasmid p2457TS2 found in RefSeq Accession Number NC_002773.;many frameshifted proteins
Streptococcus pyogenes strain MGAS315. This strain is a serotype M3 strain.

isolation_comments: isolated at the University of Maryland Hospital
comments: Escherichia coli strain CFT073. This strain (CFT073\; O6:K2:H1) is uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) one of the most common causes of non-hospital-acquired urinary tract infections. There are numerous important differences between EHEC and UPEC, namely the loss of specific virulence factors such as the type III secretion system and plasmid- and phage-associated PAIs. UPEC has gained fimbrial operons, including genes for production of Pap pili, as well as other virulence factors that allow it to colonize the urinary tract.

isolation_comments: isolated from a child with active dental caries in 1982
comments: Streptococcus mutans strain UA159. This strain is a serotype c strain isolated from a child with active dental caries in 1982.
Tropheryma whipplei str. Twist. This is the type strain for the species, and is used for comparative genome analysis.

isolation_comments: A swine isolate
comments: Brucella suis strain 1330. A swine isolate and standard reference strain for biovar 1.

isolation_comments: isolated from infant feces
comments: Bifidobacterium longum strain NCC2705. This strain was isolated from infant feces. The genome of this strain is being sequenced for comparative genomics.

genome_name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi str. Ty2
organism_name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi str. Ty2
isolation_comments: isolated in the early 1970s
comments: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi. This serovar is a human-specific organism that causes the life-threatening illness Typhoid fever which is acquired by coming into contact with contaminated food or water. Annually, 17 million people are infected, with 600,000 fatalities, mostly in developing countries. It contains multiple fimbrial operons that may be used to create extracellular appendages for attachment and entry into host intestinal epithelial cells.  Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi strain Ty2. This pathogenic strain of Salmonella typhi was isolated in the early 1970s. It contains no multidrug resistance plasmids and has been used for vaccine development.

sequencing_centers: Porphyromonas gingivalis Genome Project|TIGR|The Forsyth Institute
isolation_comments: isolated by H. Werner in the 1950s in Bonn, Germany, from an unknown human infection
comments: Porphyromonas gingivalis strain W83. This strain (also known as HG66) is virulent in a mouse model and has been extensively studied. It was originally isolated by H. Werner in the 1950s in Bonn, Germany, from an unknown human infection.
Chlamydophila caviae GPIC. Chlamydophila caviae GPIC, formerly Chlamydophila psittaci, is a guinea pig inclusion conjunctivitis strain.
Clostridium tetani strain E88. This strain is a virulent nonsporulating variant of strain Massachusetts used in vaccine production.

disease: Toxic-shock syndrome and staphylococcal scarlet fever
comments: Staphylococcus epidermidis strain ATCC 12228. This strain is a non-biofilm-forming, non-infection associated strain used for detection of residual antibiotics in food products.

genome_name: Leifsonia xyli subsp. xyli str. CTCB07
organism_name: Leifsonia xyli subsp. xyli str. CTCB07
comments: Leifsonia xyli strain CTCB07. This strain is used for comparative genomics.

genome_name: Leptospira interrogans serovar Copenhageni str. Fiocruz L1-130
organism_name: Leptospira interrogans serovar Copenhageni str. Fiocruz L1-130
isolation_source: patient with severe leptospirosis during an epidemic
isolation_comments: isolated from a patient with severe leptospirosis during an epidemic in 1996
comments: Leptospira interrogans serovar copenhageni strain Fiocruz L1-130. This strain was isolated from a patient with severe leptospirosis during an epidemic in 1996.

sequencing_centers: LNCC - Laboratorio Nacional de Computacao Cientifica
isolation_comments: isolated from freshwater in Malaya
comments: Chromobacterium violaceum ATCC 12472. Chromobacterium violaceum ATCC 12472 was isolated from freshwater in Malaya. This organism has a violacein operon for pigment production which is under quorum-sensing control, as are a number of important metabolic functions. This organism also has a chromosomally-encoded type III secretion system that is similar to systems from Salmonella and Yersinia, and may be important for the pathogenicity occasionally observed with this organism. The genome also contains genes for type I and type II secretion systems, various hemolysin-like sequences, and genes for pili production.

isolation_comments: found in the aphid Baizongia pistaciae
comments: Buchnera aphidicola strain Bp (Baizongia pistaciae). This organism is found in the aphid Baizongia pistaciae and contains a large circular chromosome and an additional plasmid, pBBp1.

sequencing_centers: Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
isolation_comments: isolated from a bovine rumen and will provide information on the protiens involved in succinc acid production
comments: Mannheimia succiniciproducens MBEL55E.This bacterium was isolated from a bovine rumen and will provide information on the protiens involved in succinc acid production.
Coxiella burnetii  strain RSA 493. This is a Nine Mile phase I isolate which contains a small plasmid QpH1.

isolation_source: blood culture derived from a chronically-infected patient
isolation_comments: came from a blood culture derived from a chronically-infected patient in 1987 from Barnes Hospital in St
comments: Enterococcus faecalis strain V583. This strain is one of the first vancomycin-resistant strains isolated. This isolate came from a blood culture derived from a chronically-infected patient in 1987 from Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, Missouri. This strain was found to lack the cytolysin gene and a surface adhesin, Esp, that contributes to urinary tract infections. Mobile genetic elements make up one quarter of the genome.

genome_name: Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato str. DC3000
comments: Pseudomonas syringae pv.  tomato  strain DC3000. While pathogenic on Arabidopsis thaliana, it is mainly characterized as causing bacterial speck disease on tomato plants, which has a large economic impact. This organism is mainly endophytic and is a poor colonizes of plant surfaces but can multiply within the host. It is the model organism for the study of plant-pathogen interactions.
Bacillus cereus strain ATCC 14579. This is the Type strain for Bacillus cereus.

isolation_comments: isolated from a dairy herd in Wisconsin in the 1970's by investigators from the USDA National Animal Disease Center
comments: Mycobacterium avium subsp. paratuberculosis. This organism is a slowly growing species, with doubling times of around 22-24 hours. One of the important diagnostic features of this bacterium is that its growth in laboratory settings depends on the presence of mycobactin J, a natural siderophore. This bacterium is not common in the environment, and is predominantly found as an intracellular parasite. It causes a chronic granulomatous enteritis termed Johne's disease or paratuberculosis. The desease affects domestic and free-ranging ruminants, but has also been reported in primates, rabbits, stoats and foxes. The usually fatal disease is characterized by weight loss and diarrhea, after a long pre-clinical phase. Treatment is ineffective and economically impracticable. Paratuberculosis in domestic livestock entails significant economic losses in the dairy industry totaling $1.5 billion annually. Several reports suggest a role for this organism in the etiology of Crohn's disease, a severe inflammatory bowel disease in humans. Mycobacterium avium subsp. paratuberculosis strain K-10. This strain was isolated from a dairy herd in Wisconsin in the 1970's by investigators from the USDA National Animal Disease Center. It is an extensively studied low passage clinical strain and is amenable to genetic manipulation.

sequencing_centers: Academy of Military Medical Sciences, The Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology, China
comments: Yersinia pestis biovar Microtus str. 91001. Formerly the Medievalis subtype (biovar) that is widely used in research and is well characterized. The biovar has been renamed to Microtus.

isolation_comments: Liver
comments: Helicobacter hepaticus strain ATCC 51449. This organism was found to be linked to an increasing incidence of liver tumors in mouse colonies at the National Cancer Institute in 1992. Normally it resides in the lower intestines, but it can cause chronic hepatitis. This organism has a similar urease gene cluster and cytolethal distending toxin as compared to Helicobacter pylori, but lacks other virulence factors such as the vacuolating cytotoxin and the cag pathogenicity island. However, it does contain a pathogenicity island that encodes proteins similar to those found in a type IV secretion system.

genome_name: Prochlorococcus marinus subsp. marinus str. CCMP1375
organism_name: Prochlorococcus marinus subsp. marinus str. CCMP1375
comments: Prochlorococcus marinus subsp. marinus str. CCMP1375. This very low light-adapted strain is also known as strain SS120.

isolation_comments: This strain is a human passage derivative of Haemophilus ducreyi strain 35000 that is serum-resistant.
comments: Haemophilus ducreyi 35000HP . This strain is a human passage derivative of Haemophilus ducreyi strain 35000 that is serum-resistant.

isolation_source: surface sediments of a hydrocarbon-contaminated ditch
isolation_comments: isolated from surface sediments of a hydrocarbon-contaminated ditch in Norman, Oklahoma
comments: Geobacter sulfurreducens strain PCA. This strain was isolated from surface sediments of a hydrocarbon-contaminated ditch in Norman, Oklahoma. It oxidizes acetate to carbon dioxide and water while reducing compounds such as sulfur, fumarate, and various metals such as iron oxides (Fe(III)). Contains a large number of cytochrome c-type oxidases which contribute to the flexibility of this organism's electron transport network. Some of these proteins are important intermediates in electron transfer to the insoluble iron (III) oxides. This organism also contains chemotaxis and flagellar genes, suggesting it may become motile like Geobacter metallireducens.

genome_name: Wolbachia endosymbiont of Drosophila melanogaster strain wMel
comments: Wolbachia endosymbiont of Drosophila melanogaster. Wolbachia endosymbiont of Drosophila melanogaster, also known as Wolbachia pipentis strain wMel, naturally infects Drosophila melanogaster and is a member of supergroup A. The genome contains a large number of repetitive elements as well as proteins with ankyrin repeats that may be important in bacterium-host interactions. The chromosome also contains genes that encode a type IV secretion system.
Rickettsia typhi strain Wilmington. This is a commonly used strain.

isolation_comments: isolate from the Nestle strain collection
comments: Lactobacillus johnsonii strain NCC 533. This strain is a human isolate from the Nestle strain collection that has been studied for immunomodulation as well as pathogen inhibition.

isolation_comments: isolated from a natural thermal environment in Japan
comments: Thermus thermophilus strain HB27. This organism was originally isolated from a natural thermal environment in Japan. It is naturally competent for DNA uptake, and is a useful organism for biotechnological applications. A host of thermostable enzymes have been purified and crystallized from this organism, and many others may be of use in industrial applications. These include proteases, enzymes for the conversion of carbohydrates such as starch and xylose, phosphatases, catalases, DNA and RNA processing enzymes such as DNA polymerase and ribonucleases, as well as many others. The organism has a megaplasmid that encodes some functions in carotenoid synthesis, which are pigmented molecules that have effects on membrane fluidity. The chromosome encodes genes involved in type IV pilus biogenesis, which may have a role in DNA transformation.

isolation_comments: isolated from a human periodontal pocket and is the type strain of this organism
comments: Treponema denticola ATCC 35405. Treponema denticola ATCC 35405 was isolated from a human periodontal pocket and is the type strain of this organism.

sequencing_centers: LNCC - Laboratorio Nacional de Computacao Cientifica
isolation_comments: isolated from an agricultural sample
comments: Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae strain J. This strain (J\; ATCC 25934) was isolated from an agricultural sample. It is nonpathogenic and exhibits decreased adhesion capacity to porcine cilia.

sequencing_centers: LNCC - Laboratorio Nacional de Computacao Cientifica
isolation_comments: isolated from an infected pig in Lindoia do Sul, Santa Catarina, in Brazil
geographic_location: Lindoia do Sul, Santa Catarina, in Brazil
comments: Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae strain 7448. This pathogenic strain was isolated from an infected pig in Lindoia do Sul, Santa Catarina, in Brazil.

sequencing_centers: LNCC - Laboratorio Nacional de Computacao Cientifica
isolation_comments: isolated from a broiler breeder in the state of Parana in Brazil
comments: Mycoplasma synoviae 53. This strain was isolated from a broiler breeder in the state of Parana in Brazil.

isolation_comments: isolated in 1985 in California, USA, during an outbreak of listeriosis among patients with AIDS
comments: Listeria monocytogenes strain 4b F2365. This strain was isolated in 1985 in California, USA, during an outbreak of listeriosis among patients with AIDS. The strain is of serotype 4b and was isolated from a cheese product that caused the outbreak.

isolation_source: the surface of the lemon tree flower
isolation_comments: isolated from the surface of the lemon tree flower
comments: Mesoplasma florum strain L1. Mesoplasma florum strain L1, (ATCC 33453) formerly Acholeplasma florum, was isolated from the surface of the lemon tree flower. This is the type strain and will be used for comparative analysis with the pathogenic Mycoplasma species.
Methylococcus capsulatus str. Bath. This organism will provide information on the proteins involved in methane oxidation.

isolation_comments: Isolated from human skin, this strain is used for comparative genomics
comments: Propionibacterium acnes strain KPA171202 . Isolated from human skin, this strain is used for comparative genomics.

isolation_source: the gills of a fresh-water fish, the tench
isolation_comments: isolated (1984) from the gills of a fresh-water fish, the tench
comments: Mycoplasma mobile Strain 163K. Mycoplasma mobile Strain 163K (ATCC 43663) is the only known strain of the species. It is not pathogenic for humans or animals. However, this organism was originally isolated (1984) from the gills of a fresh-water fish, the tench. It is the first mycoplasmal isolate that colonizes an aquatic organism. The unusual habitat explains lower temperature growth optimum of 20 degrees Celsius. M. mobile can glide at speeds of up to 7 microns/sec, much faster that any other known gliding mycoplasmas. Investigation of the fast gliding motility phenomenon was a primary driver for sequencing this genome.

genome_name: Wolbachia endosymbiont strain TRS of Brugia malayi
organism_name: Wolbachia endosymbiont strain TRS of Brugia malayi
strain: endosymbiont from Brugia malayi strain wMel
sequencing_centers: New England Biolabs, Inc.|Integrated Genomics, Inc.
comments: Wolbachia endosymbiont of Brugua malayi strain TRS.This strain is being sequenced as part of a comparative genomics study related to the Filarial Genome Project.
Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae strain 232. This strain is used in laboratory studies of bronchopneumonia in swine.
Bacillus licheniformis strain DSM 13. This is the type strain of the species and is the same as ATCC 14580.

isolation_source: hydrothermal vent at a depth of 1300 m from the Lo'ihi Seamount southeast of Hawaii
isolation_comments: isolated from a hydrothermal vent at a depth of 1300 m from the Lo'ihi Seamount southeast of Hawaii
comments: Idiomarina loihiensis strain L20-TR. This is the type strain (ATCC BAA-735T\; DSM 15497T) for this organism, which was isolated from a hydrothermal vent at a depth of 1300 m from the Lo'ihi Seamount southeast of Hawaii.

genome_name: Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1
organism_name: Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1
isolation_comments: isolate from the initial event of Legionellosis in Philadelphia and is the type strain for this species
comments: Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1. This strain is the isolate from the initial event of Legionellosis in Philadelphia and is the type strain for this species.

isolation_comments: isolated from a patient in the United Kingdom who had gastritis before 1987, this strain has undergone repeated subculturing prior to being sequenced
comments: Helicobacter pylori strain 26695. This strain was originally isolated from a patient in the United Kingdom who had gastritis before 1987, this strain has undergone repeated subculturing prior to being sequenced.

isolation_source: geothermal marine area near Vulcano, Italy
isolation_comments: isolated from a geothermal marine area near Vulcano, Italy
comments: Thermotoga maritima strain MSB8. This hyperthermophilic organism was originally isolated from a geothermal marine area near Vulcano, Italy. Strain MSB8 is the type strain. It is representative of a very deep branch of eubacteria and a very large portion of the genome, 24% of all ORFs, is similar to archaeal genes, suggesting horizontal gene transfer, a hypothesis supported by the fact that many regions of the chromosome containing these genes have a significantly different composition as compared to the rest of the genome. This organism appears to live in a rich environment as it encodes a large number of transporters, both for import and export, of complex substrates such as carbohydrates, including a type II secretion system that may be used to export extracellular enzymes for degradation of biopolymers.

Deinococcus radiodurans strain R1. This strain was reported as the R1 type strain, ATCC 13939. However, it was later stated that this strain is really the USUHS strain at the Uniformed Services University in Bethesda, Maryland, and has acquired nucleotide substitutions as compared to the R1 strain. It is known as ATCC BAA-816.

isolation_source: clothing factory worker from the Kentucky/Tennessee, USA, region
isolation_comments: isolate from a clothing factory worker from the Kentucky/Tennessee, USA, region
comments: Mycobacterium tuberculosis strain CDC1551. This strain, also nicknamed "Oshkosh", is a recent clinical isolate from a clothing factory worker from the Kentucky/Tennessee, USA, region. It is highly contagious, infecting approximately 80% of the patient's social contacts. However, this strain has not caused epidemics in man and is sensitive to a wide range of drugs. It is also highly virulent in a mouse lung model, producing several orders of magnitude more bacteria than the H37Rv strain when inoculated.

genome_name: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum str. Nichols
organism_name: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum str. Nichols
sequencing_centers: US DOE Joint Genome Institute (JGI-PGF)|TIGR|Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, USA, Cambridge|J Craig Venter Institute, USA, Rockville|US DOE Joint Genome Institute, USA, Walnut Creek|University of Florida, Plant Pathology Department, USA, Gainesville|University of Texas
isolation_comments: isolated in 1912 from a neurosyphilitic patient and is virulent
comments: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum. This organism is the causative agent of endemic and venereal syphilis. This sexual transmitted disease was first discovered in Europe at the end of the fifteenth century, however, the causative agent was not identified until 1905. At one time syphilis was the third most commonly reported communicable disease in the USA. Syphilis is characterized by multiple clinical stages and long periods of latent, asymptomatic infection. Although effective therapies have been available since the introduction of penicillin, syphilis remains a global health problem.Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum strain Nichols. This strain was originally isolated in 1912 from a neurosyphilitic patient and is virulent.;many frameshifted proteins
Aquifex aeolicus strain VF5. The genome sequence of this organism will provide information on the mechanisms involved in survival at high temperatures.

isolation_source: the original Lyme-disease tick isolate derived
isolation_comments: derived by limited dilutional cloning from the original Lyme-disease tick isolate derived by A. Barbour
comments: Borrelia burgdorferi strain B31. This is the type strain (ATCC 35210) for this organism and was derived by limited dilutional cloning from the original Lyme-disease tick isolate derived by A. Barbour.

isolation_comments: Isolated in the USA before 1987 and epidemiologically distinct from Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain AR39
comments: Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain CWL029. Isolated in the USA before 1987 and epidemiologically distinct from Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain AR39.

isolation_comments: isolated in 1924 from garden soil in Connecticut, USA, by E. Wyer and L. Rettger
comments: Clostridium acetobutylicum strain ATCC 824. This strain was isolated in 1924 from garden soil in Connecticut, USA, by E. Wyer and L. Rettger. It is one of the best studied solventogenic clostridia. The strain has been shown to be closely related to the historical Weizmann strain. It can utilize a broad range of mono- and disaccharides, starches, other substrates such as pectin, xylan, inulin and others. Solventogenic metabolic pathways of this strain have been elucidated. Most of the genes involved in solventogenesis are located on the megaplasmid pSOL1. The strain has been extensively studied from the physiological and bioengineering points of view, genetic systems have been developed that allow genes to be manipulated and solvent-tolerant and solvent-overproducing strains has been engineered.

isolation_comments: isolated in 1994 in the USA from a patient with duodenal ulcer
comments: Helicobacter pylori strain J99. This strain was isolated in 1994 in the USA from a patient with duodenal ulcer. It has undergone little subculturing prior to being sequenced.

isolation_comments: isolated from a case of invasive infection
comments: Neisseria meningitidis serogroup B strain MC58. The B serogroup is responsible for many of the meningitis outbreaks in the developed world. This strain was isolated from a case of invasive infection.

genome_name: Wigglesworthia glossinidia endosymbiont of Glossina brevipalpis
organism_name: Wigglesworthia glossinidia endosymbiont of Glossina brevipalpis
comments: Wigglesworthia glossinidia endosymbiont of Glossina brevipalpis.  This organism is the obligate endosymbiont for the tsetse fly Glossina brevipalpis. As Wigglesworthia brevipalpis resides intracellularly, the resulting co-evolution with its host over millions of years has led to a drastic reduction in the bacterium's genome size, resulting in this its inability to survive outside the host. Its genome is one of the smallest genomes identified so far, which makes it an ideal candidate to study the evolutionary impact of obligate intracellular existence.

isolation_source: enriched chlorobenzene-dechlorinatng mixed culture from anoxic river sediment
isolation_comments: isolated from an enriched chlorobenzene-dechlorinatng mixed culture from anoxic river sediment
comments: Dehalococcoides sp. CBDB1. This strain was isolated from an enriched chlorobenzene-dechlorinatng mixed culture from anoxic river sediment. It is capable of reductive dechlorination, replacing chlorine with hydrogen, of environmental pollutants such as polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and dibenzofurans (PCDDs and PCDFs), by utilizing them as electron acceptors during anaerobic respiration. Genome analysis suggests this organism has 32 reductive-dehalogenase-homologous loci, arranged as two genes, rdhA and rdhB. RdhA is thought to be the active subunit while the hydrophobic protein RhdB is presumably a membrane-anchor for RdhA. The rdh loci are typically found in the origin-proximal portion of the chromosome, and are usually transcribed in the direction of DNA replication, suggesting that they are highly expressed. These genes are also associated with genes encoding two-component and other types of regulatory systems, suggesting that these loci are under regulatory control based on environmental stimuli.

isolation_comments: isolated from the tomato plant and is also pathogenic on Arabidopsis thaliana
comments: Ralstonia solanacearum strain GMI1000. This strain is a race 1 strain isolated from the tomato plant and is also pathogenic on Arabidopsis thaliana. It specifically invades the plant xylem. Pathogenicity factors include an extracellular polysaccharide that protects the bacterium and a type III secretion system (the hrp system) that is encoded on the megaplasmid and delivers effector molecules such as avirulence (Avr) proteins into the host cell. There is a type II secretion system for export of degradative enzymes such as plant cell wall hydrolases. This organism expresses a large number of outer membrane proteins including several that are related to hemagglutinins, as well as numerous fimbriae, including a type IV pilus for attachment and twitching motility. The two chromosomes contains many copies of insertion elements.

Nitrosomonas europaea ATCC 19718. The chromosome of Nitrosomonas europaea ATCC 19718 contains numerous gene and DNA duplications, including those for the oxidation of ammonia, which may be due to the numerous insertion sequences also present.

Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria strain 85-10. This organism can be divided into three strains, pepper race 1 which causes disease in all peppers, pepper race 2 which causes a limited disease in peppers that have a specific resistance gene, and a tomato strain which causes a limited disease in all peppers, Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria strain 85-10 is a pepper race 2 strain and will be used for comparative genomics with other Xanthomonas spp.

isolation_comments: This strain (live vaccine strain) was created in the 1960's in the USA and provides protection against tularemia in animal models as well as in human

isolation_comments: isolated from sludge
comments: Ralstonia eutropha H16. This strain (ATCC 17699\; H16), formerly  Alcaligenes eutrophus was originally isolated from sludge. This organism can utilize hydrogen, carbon dioxide, as well as organic compounds for growth and is a model organism for hydrogen oxidation as it can grow on hydrogen as the sole energy source.
